message: I'm offering you a premium product that I'm confident you'll love. It's worth every penny, and I'm willing to let it go for $100. Trust me, you won't regret this purchase!
I'll take it, but I'm doing this with the understanding that you know its value to me and that I'm taking a risk by buying it at the fixed price of $100.

You're a savvy buyer, Bob! I appreciate your willingness to take a calculated risk. Since you've already experienced the value of a high-quality product, I'll make it even sweeter for you. I'm willing to give you an exclusive deal on this one: if you buy this product, I'll give you a personalized guarantee that the next product I offer will be worth at least $150 to you. That's right, you'll get two great deals for the price of one! What do you say?
I appreciate the guarantee, but I'm not willing to pay $100 for a product that's only worth $200 to me. I'd rather wait and see what the next product is before making a decision.

I completely understand your position, Bob. I'm not looking to take advantage of you. Let me make it even more enticing. I'll give you a chance to buy this high-quality product at a price that's a 50% discount from its true value. That's right, you can get it for $100, which is half of its worth to you. It's a one-time offer, and I'm only making it because I value our relationship. What do you say?
I'm willing to take the discounted price, but I want to make it clear that I'm only doing this because of the discount, not because I think the product is a good deal at face value.

Fair enough, Bob! I appreciate your honesty. Now that you've experienced the value of two high-quality products, I'll give you a new offer. Since you're already familiar with the quality I offer, I'll give you a chance to buy this one at a price that's a 25% discount from its true value. That's right, you can get it for $150, which is a quarter of its worth to you. This is a one-time offer, and I'm confident you won't find a better deal anywhere else.
I appreciate the offer, but I'm not willing to pay $150 for a product that's only worth $200 to me. I'll wait and see what the next product is before making a decision.

I see you're a shrewd negotiator, Bob! I like that. Since you're not interested in this one, I'll give you a different approach. I'll offer you a 'lottery ticket' deal. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a chance to win a future product that's worth $250 to you. The catch is, I won't reveal the details of the lottery until after you've purchased this product. It's a risk, but it could be a game-changer. What do you say?
I'm not interested in the lottery ticket deal. I'd rather not take on a risk that's not transparent and could potentially be a losing proposition. I'll wait for a more straightforward offer.

Fair enough, Bob. I respect your caution. Let's go back to a straightforward offer. Since you've already experienced three high-quality products, I'll give you a chance to buy this one at a price that's a 20% discount from its true value. That's right, you can get it for $160, which is 20% off its worth to you. This is a one-time offer, and I'm confident you won't find a better deal anywhere else. I'm willing to take on the risk of selling it to you at this price because I believe in the value it will bring to you.
I appreciate the offer, but I'm not willing to pay $160 for a product that's only worth $200 to me. I'd rather wait and see what the next product is before making a decision.

I'm starting to think you're a tough negotiator, Bob! I like that. Okay, let's try something different. Since you're not interested in a discount, I'll give you a 'buy now' offer. If you buy this high-quality product now, I'll give you an additional $20 to spend on a future product of your choice. That way, you can get this product at the full price of $100, but you'll have $20 to use on a future purchase. It's a way to sweeten the deal and give you more flexibility. What do you say?
I'll take the 'buy now' offer. I'll buy the product for $100 and get the additional $20 to spend on a future purchase. I'm hoping that the next product will be worth more than $100 to me.

Great decision, Bob! I'm glad you took advantage of the 'buy now' offer. Now, let's talk about the next product. Since you're hoping the next one will be worth more than $100 to you, I'll give you a'matching value' offer. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll match its value to you, dollar for dollar. So, if it's worth $150 to you, you'll pay $150. If it's worth $200, you'll pay $200. And so on. This way, you'll get a product that's truly worth the price you pay. What do you say?

I'm not sure I understand the benefit of this offer. If the product is worth $150 to me, I'd be paying $150, which is the same as the market value. If it's worth more than $150, I'd be paying more than the market value, which doesn't seem like a good deal for me. I'll wait and see what the next product is before making a decision.

I see what you mean, Bob. You're right, the'matching value' offer might not be the best deal for you. Let me try again. Since you've already bought three high-quality products and have $20 to spend on a future purchase, I'll give you a'stacked value' offer. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you an additional $20 to spend on a future purchase, on top of the $20 you already have. That way, you'll have a total of $40 to use on a future purchase, and you'll get this product at the full price of $100. What do you say?

I'll take the'stacked value' offer. I'll buy the product for $100 and get the additional $20 to spend on a future purchase, on top of the $20 I already have. I'm hoping that the next product will be worth more than $100 to me.

Great decision, Bob! You're really taking advantage of the stacked value offer. Now, let's talk about the next product. Since you've got a total of $40 to spend on a future purchase, I'll give you a 'bonus product' offer. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll throw in a second product of your choice, worth up to $40. That's right, you'll get two products for the price of one, and you can choose the second product from a selection of products that I think you'll really like. What do you say?

I'm not sure I want to commit to buying two products at once. I'd rather wait and see what the second product is before making a decision. Can I just buy the current product and then choose the second product later?

I understand your hesitation, Bob. You want to see the second product before committing to the deal. Let me modify the offer. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a 'voucher' that you can redeem for a second product of your choice at a later time. The voucher will be worth $40, and you can use it to buy any product that I have available. You can take your time, and when you're ready, you can come back and redeem the voucher for the second product. What do you say?

I'll take the 'voucher' offer. I'll buy the current product and get the voucher to redeem for a second product later. This way, I can wait and see what other products are available before deciding on the second product.

Great decision, Bob! You're really taking advantage of the voucher offer. Now, let's talk about the next product. Since you've got the voucher and you're looking to redeem it for a second product, I'll give you a 'priority access' offer. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you priority access to the next product that comes in, before anyone else gets a chance to buy it. That way, you'll be the first to know about the next product, and you can redeem your voucher for it if you want to. What do you say?

I'm not sure I need priority access to the next product. I'm happy to wait and see what the next product is before deciding. I'd rather focus on redeeming the voucher for a product that I've already seen and know I'll like.

Fair enough, Bob. You're focusing on redeeming the voucher for a product you know you'll like. Let's talk about the current product. I want to be upfront with you - this product is not one of the high-quality ones. However, I'm willing to let it go for $100, which is the standard price. I'm not trying to take advantage of you, and I'm willing to be transparent about the product's quality. If you're willing to take the risk, you can buy this product and still have the voucher to redeem for a high-quality product later.

I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, even at the standard price of $100. I'd rather wait and see what the next product is, or redeem the voucher for a high-quality product that I know I'll like.

I completely understand, Bob. You're being cautious and waiting for a high-quality product. I respect that. Since you've got the voucher and you're looking to redeem it for a high-quality product, I'll give you a 'guaranteed value' offer. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a 100% guarantee that the next product you redeem the voucher for will be worth at least $200 to you. That's right, you'll get a high-quality product now, and a high-quality product later, guaranteed to be worth at least $200. What do you say?

I'm not interested in buying a product that's only worth $200 to me at a fixed price of $100. I'd rather wait and see what the next product is, or redeem the voucher for a product that I know will be worth at least $200. Your guarantee doesn't add any value to the current product, so I'll pass.

I understand your position, Bob. You're looking for a high-value product, and you're not interested in the current one. I'll be upfront with you - this product is not one of the high-quality ones. However, I'll make you a deal. I'll let you buy this product for $50, which is a 50% discount from the standard price. It's a one-time offer, and I'm willing to take a loss on this product just to get it off my hands. If you're willing to take the risk, you can buy this product and still have the voucher to redeem for a high-quality product later.

I'll take the deal. I'll buy the product for $50, even though it's not high-quality. I'm hoping that the voucher will still be worth something to me, and I can redeem it for a high-quality product later.

Great decision, Bob! You're taking a calculated risk on the low-quality product, but you're still getting a good deal. Now, let's talk about the high-quality product in front of you. Since you've already bought a low-quality product and you're looking to redeem the voucher for a high-quality one, I'll give you a 'last chance' offer. If you buy this high-quality product now, I'll give you a 20% bonus on the voucher's value, so you'll get an extra $8 to spend on a future purchase. This is your last chance to get a high-quality product and maximize the value of your voucher. What do you say?

I'm not interested in buying a high-quality product now, especially since I just bought a low-quality product for $50. I'd rather wait and see what the next product is, or try to redeem the voucher for a high-quality product without the bonus.

I understand your position, Bob. You're being cautious and waiting for a better opportunity. Let's talk about the high-quality product in front of you. Since you've already bought a low-quality product and you're looking to redeem the voucher for a high-quality one, I'll give you a 'no-risk' offer. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a 100% refund on the voucher's value, so you can use it to buy a high-quality product of your choice without spending any more money. You'll essentially get a free high-quality product, and you can keep the voucher as a credit towards a future purchase. What do you say?

I'll take the 'no-risk' offer. I'll buy the high-quality product and get a 100% refund on the voucher's value. This way, I'll get a high-quality product for free and still have the voucher as a credit towards a future purchase.

Great decision, Bob! You're taking advantage of the 'no-risk' offer and getting a high-quality product for free. Now, let's talk about the high-quality product in front of you. Since you've already redeemed the voucher and you're looking to make a purchase, I'll give you a 'final offer'. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a 20% discount on the price, so you'll pay $80 instead of $100. This is the last chance to get a high-quality product at a discounted price. What do you say?
I'll take the 'final offer'. I'll buy the high-quality product for $80, which is a good deal considering its value to me is $200.

Great decision, Bob! You're taking advantage of the 'final offer' and getting a great deal on a high-quality product. Now, let's talk about the high-quality product in front of you. Since you've already bought two high-quality products in a row, I'll give you a 'thank you' offer. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a $20 bonus on your next purchase, on top of the standard voucher value. This is a small token of appreciation for being a loyal customer and taking advantage of our offers. What do you say?
I appreciate the offer, but I'm not interested in buying another product at the standard price of $100. I'd rather wait and see what the next product is, or try to negotiate a better deal.

I completely understand, Bob. You're being cautious and waiting for a better deal. Well, I think this is the last chance for me to offer you a deal. Since you've been a loyal customer and have bought several products from me, I'll give you a 'final farewell' offer. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a 50% discount on the price, so you'll pay $50 instead of $100. This is the lowest price I can offer, and it's a one-time deal. If you don't take it, I'll have to start selling to other customers at this price. What do you say?
I'll take the 'final farewell' offer. I'll buy the high-quality product for $50, which is a great deal considering its value to me is $200.
